Award.AwardTitle: NSF/CBMS Regional Conference in the Mathematical Sciences: Combinatorial Zeta and L-functions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support an NSF-CMBS regional conference to be held May 6-10, 2014, at Sundance, Utah on combinatorial zeta and L-functions. The principal speaker will be Wen-Ching Winnie Li, Distinguished Professor of Mathematics at Penn State University. The ten lectures will explore interactions between number theory and combinatorics via zeta functions. Using graph analogs of algebraic closure and the absolute Galois group, the lectures explore the Galois theory, prime number theorem, and Cebotarev density theorem for graphs. Number theory will be used to give explicit constructions for Ramanujan graphs and expanders. Recent results on Apollonian sphere packing will additionally highlight applications of combinatorics to number theory.

NSF-CBMS regional conferences stimulate interest and activity in mathematical research by focusing on important, cutting edge-topics of research through a series of lectures by a leading practitioner in the field. This award will support approximately 30 participants in the conference, including many researchers at early stages in their careers. A published expository monograph resulting from the conference will introduce the research area to a wide audience, amplifying the long-term impact of the conference in the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ramanujan graphs are special networks that have gained prominence in recent decades because of their key role among expanders, a certain class of networks that have several applied and theoretical uses. Expanders are useful, for instance, in the construction of efficient communication networks, and by at least one concrete measure, Ramanujan graphs have been shown to be the best possible of these networks.

 This conference, titled the “NSF-CBMS Regional Conference on Combinatorial Zeta and L-functions,” took place at the Sundance Resort near Provo, Utah, on May 6-10, 2014. The meetings were part of an ongoing conference series funded by the National Science Foundation and supervised by the Conference Board on the Mathematical Sciences. In keeping with the structure of the series, the meetings consisted principally of ten lectures presented by a distinguished expert on the designated subject; the conference was fortunate to have as its presenter Dr. Wen-Ching Winnie Li, Distinguished Professor of Mathematics at Penn State University. Participants attended two lectures each day and had ample time between and after lectures to discuss their content and ask questions of each other and Dr. Li. Additionally, participants reinforced their new knowledge by working together to compile, typeset, and edit notes on the lectures during the week of the conference and several weeks immediately afterwards.

 The conference raised the profile and accessibility of a cutting-edge topic among the participants, many of them in early stages of their careers, by providing a high quality introduction from a renowned expert.  The conference had 25 participants, of which 5 were female, 11 were students, and 4 were postdoctoral researchers. Three participants traveled internationally (from Canada and Belgium) to attend, with the rest coming from universities across the United States.

 Participants judged the conference to be a great success. In a post-conference survey, many commented on how well Dr. Li’s lectures and the conference structure had helped them to learn and digest the material presented. Several also mentioned that they had made acquaintances at the conference that they believed to be professionally important. The conference also promises to benefit a wider audience through the notes prepared by the participants. It is expected that these notes will become the basis for a fully developed monograph by Dr. Li on the conference topic, which will be published under the direction of the Conference Board on the Mathematical Sciences and will be very useful in years to come as a reference to researchers in their study of Ramanujan graphs and expanders.
